Article.ArticleTitle: Ozone and cardiac arrest: The role of previous hospitalizations.

AbstractText: Several studies have reported associations between exposure to particulate matter and incidence of out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) and some have observed associations with ozone (O<sub>3</sub>). There are no studies investigating susceptibility based on previous disease history to short-term O<sub>3</sub> exposure and the risk of OHCA.
To investigate the role of previous cardiovascular-related hospitalizations in modifying the associations between the risk of OHCA and short-term increase in O<sub>3</sub> concentrations.

A time-stratified case-crossover analysis of 11,923 OHCA registered in the Swedish Register for Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation from 2006 to 2014 was performed. Using personal identification numbers, OHCA were linked to all previous hospitalizations in Sweden since 1987 to create susceptible groups based on the principal diagnosis code at discharge. Susceptibility was based on hospitalization for i) acute myocardial infarction; ii) heart failure; iii) arrhythmias; iv) diabetes; v) hypertension; and vi) stroke. Moving 2 and 24-h averages for O<sub>3</sub>, PM<sub>2.5</sub>, PM<sub>10</sub>, and NO<sub>2</sub> were constructed from hourly averages.

A 10 μg/m<sup>3</sup> higher 2-h average O<sub>3</sub> concentration was associated with a 2% higher risk of OHCA (95% CI, 0% 3%). Associations were similar for 24-h average O<sub>3</sub> and in individuals with or without hospitalizations for AMI, heart failure, diabetes, hypertension or stroke. Individuals with previous hospitalizations for arrhythmias had a lower risk of OHCA with higher O<sub>3</sub>. No associations were observed for other pollutants.

Short-term exposure to O<sub>3</sub> was associated with an elevated risk of OHCA, however, previous hospitalizations for cardiovascular diseases were not associated with additionally augmented risks.
